title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to eligible entities for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative vehicles, energy efficiency standards for public buildings, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, and financing for energy efficiency improvements. The program includes on-bill financing for energy efficiency, State tax incentives for clean energy, innovative financing mechanisms, best management practices for public utility commissions, grid technology updates, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities for grants include States, local governments, and regional consortia. The program offers grants for implementing carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application for review. The Secretary will determine grant recipients based on application information and criteria for evaluation. The Secretary will provide grants based on application information and criteria for evaluation. Grant funds must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary. Regulations will establish criteria for grants, eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing applications. The Secretary will establish regulations for grants, including criteria for eligible measures and application evaluation. Considerations will include regional energy disparities and clean energy potential. An explanation of grant evaluation criteria will be published in the Federal Register. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include oil related qualified production activities for major integrated oil companies. A conforming amendment excludes major integrated oil companies from a certain taxpayer provision. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.
